title: Classic Menswear Accessories
description: From tie clips to cufflinks, how well do you remember the accessories that completed a gentleman's outfit?

questions.question: What small metal clip, worn horizontally across the necktie to secure it to the shirt, was a standard men's accessory?
questions.explanation: The tie clip (or tie bar) was an essential men's accessory from the 1940s through the 1960s, keeping the necktie neatly in place against the shirt.

questions.question: What men's accessory, worn on the wrist and typically engraved with initials, was a popular gift in the 1950s and 1960s?
questions.explanation: ID bracelets, featuring a flat plate engraved with the wearer's name or initials, were a popular men's jewelry item and a common gift in the 1950s and 1960s.

questions.question: What accessory, inserted through both sides of a shirt cuff, was required for French cuff dress shirts?
questions.explanation: Cufflinks were essential for French cuff dress shirts, and a quality pair was considered a must-have for any well-dressed man. They were popular gifts.

questions.question: What square piece of fabric, folded and placed in the breast pocket of a suit jacket, was a mark of a well-dressed man?
questions.explanation: The pocket square, carefully folded and placed in the suit jacket's breast pocket, was considered essential for a polished, well-dressed appearance.

questions.question: What men's grooming product, sold in a tube or tub, was used to slick back hair in the 1950s?
questions.explanation: Brylcreem, with its famous tagline 'A little dab'll do ya,' was the go-to hair product for men in the 1950s, used to achieve the slicked-back look.

questions.question: What spring-loaded device was used to keep men's trouser creases sharp by stretching the pants overnight?
questions.explanation: Pant stretchers were spring-loaded frames inserted into trouser legs to maintain sharp creases while drying or hanging overnight.

questions.question: What alternative to a belt, consisting of Y-shaped straps worn over the shoulders to hold up trousers, was common in the 1940s?
questions.explanation: Suspenders (called braces in Britain) were the traditional way to hold up trousers before belts became standard. Many older men preferred them throughout the mid-century.

questions.question: What small decorative pin, pushed through the tie into the shirt, was used to secure a necktie before tie clips became popular?
questions.explanation: Tie pins (or stick pins) were used to secure neckties to shirts before tie clips became the norm. They often featured decorative heads with gemstones.

questions.question: What type of pocket watch chain, looped from one vest pocket to another, was a distinguished accessory for men in the 1940s?
questions.explanation: A watch fob (chain with decorative attachment) connected a pocket watch to the vest, serving both as security for the watch and as a decorative accessory.

questions.question: What style of men's wallet, long and narrow for carrying in the inside breast pocket of a suit jacket, was popular in the 1950s?
questions.explanation: Long breast pocket wallets, designed to fit in the inside jacket pocket, were the preferred wallet style for suit-wearing men in the 1950s and 1960s.

questions.question: What grooming item did well-dressed men carry in their pocket for on-the-go maintenance of their appearance?
questions.explanation: Pocket combs were carried by virtually every man in the 1950s, essential for maintaining pompadours, side parts, and other styled haircuts throughout the day.

questions.question: What monogrammed personal item was considered an essential accessory for a gentleman, used for everything from wiping brows to offering to ladies?
questions.explanation: A clean, pressed handkerchief (often monogrammed) was carried by every gentleman, used practically and offered gallantly to ladies in distress.

questions.question: What collar accessory, a narrow bar pinned under the tie knot connecting both collar points, was popular in the 1940s and 1950s?
questions.explanation: Collar pins or collar bars were worn underneath the tie knot, pulling the collar points together and pushing the tie knot forward for a refined look.

questions.question: What small metal or plastic device was inserted into dress shirt collar points to keep them stiff and straight?
questions.explanation: Collar stays, small strips inserted into pockets on the underside of shirt collars, kept the collar points straight and crisp-looking.

questions.question: What portable men's grooming set, containing items like a razor, comb, and nail file in a leather case, was a common travel gift?
questions.explanation: The Dopp kit, a leather zippered toiletry bag invented by Charles Doppelt, became the standard travel grooming case for men, and a popular gift for decades.
